abstract_summ: The aim of this study was to examine mental health (burnout, anxiety, depression, and fear) and their associated factors among frontline nurses who were caring for COVID-19 patients in Wuhan, China.Conclusions: Burnout is prevalent among healthcare workers caring for COVID-19 patients.The most commonly cited measures cited to alleviate stress/anxiety were increasing personal protective equipment availability (PPE), offering rapid COVID-19 testing at physician discretion, providing clearer communication about COVID-19 protocol changes, and assuring that physicians can take leave for care of family and self.Conclusion/Application to Practice: These findings confirmed that after a fatal infectious disease outbreak like MERS, nurses experience high level of PTSD and show high intention to leave.Stronger self-esteem and usage of humor were associated with significantly lower anxiety levels, while mental disengagement with higher anxiety levels.
title_summ: Burnout among healthcare professionals during COVID-19 pandemic: a cross-sectional studyThe inevitability of Covid-19 related distress among healthcare workers: findings from a low caseload country under lockdownWhen the storm is the strongest: The health conditions and job satisfaction of Healthcare staff and their associated predictors during the epidemic peak of COVID-19Frontline nurses’ burnout, anxiety, depression, and fear statuses and their associated factors during the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, China:The Importance of Supervisor SupportPsychological distress, coping behaviors, and preferences for support among New York healthcare workers during the COVID-19 pandemicA comparison of burnout frequency among oncology physicians and nurses working on the front lines and usual wards during the COVID-19 epidemic in Wuhan, ChinaFactors Contributing to Healthcare Professional Burnout During the COVID-19 Pandemic:A large-scale cross-sectional studyAt the height of the storm: Healthcare staff’s health conditions and job satisfaction and their associated predictors during the epidemic peak of COVID-19Anxiety and coping strategies among nursing students during the covid-19 pandemicAssessing the Presence of Post-Traumatic Stress and Turnover Intention Among Nurses Post–Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Outbreak:Factors Associated with Burnout among Healthcare Workers during an Outbreak of MERS.Academic Emergency Medicine Physicians' Anxiety Levels, Stressors and Potential Stress Mitigation Measures during the Acceleration Phase of the COVID-19 Pandemic.A Rapid Turnaround Global Survey
title_abstract_phrases: The aim of this study was to examine mental health (burnout, anxiety, depression, and fear) and their associated factors among frontline nurses who were caring for COVID-19 patients in Wuhan, China.Frontline nurses’ burnout, anxiety, depression, and fear statuses and their associated factors during the COVID-19 outbreak in Wuhan, China: A large-scale cross-sectional studyBACKGROUND: During the Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, frontline nurses face enormous mental health challenges.Conclusions: Burnout is prevalent among healthcare workers caring for COVID-19 patients.The most commonly cited measures cited to alleviate stress/anxiety were increasing personal protective equipment availability (PPE), offering rapid COVID-19 testing at physician discretion, providing clearer communication about COVID-19 protocol changes, and assuring that physicians can take leave for care of family and self.INTERPRETATION: Burnout is prevalent at higher than previously reported rates among HCPs working during the COVID-19 pandemic and is related to high workload, job stress, and time pressure, and limited organizational support.
